firstBlock.title: Oil transportation today
firstBlock.description1: Maritime transportation accounts for a significant portion of global oil shipments, with over 60% of crude oil and refined products transported by sea.
firstBlock.description2: This dominance highlights the critical role of shipping in the energy sector, as it enables countries to access vital resources efficiently and cost-effectively.

secondBlock.title: The danger of oil shipping
secondBlock.description1: However, maritime oil transportation is not without its risks, as accidents unfortunately do occur, leading to oil spills in the ocean.
secondBlock.description2: These spills have devastating effects on marine ecosystems, harming wildlife, disrupting habitats, and contaminating water sources.
secondBlock.description3: The environmental impact of such incidents can be long-lasting, affecting not only marine life but also coastal communities that rely on healthy oceans for their livelihoods.

thirdBlock.title: Our solution to the problem
thirdBlock.description1: We propose using artificial intelligence on satellites to detect oil spills and monitor the environment.
thirdBlock.description2: Satellites orbiting the Earth continuously scan vast areas of water bodies, taking high-resolution images.
thirdBlock.description3: The neural network Oil Spill AI processes these images in real time, detecting even the smallest oil spots that may pose a threat to marine ecosystems.

AboutPage.technologyText1: Our neural network uses a modified YOLOv11 architecture to segment oil slicks in satellite images. The model is trained taking into account different water areas, which allows it to accurately segment oil slicks even on heterogeneous water surfaces.
AboutPage.technologyText2: The algorithm highlights the contamination with a colored outline (by default - blue) and displays its confidence that there really is an oil slick in this area.
AboutPage.technologyText3: The system accounts for sea waves, sun glares and other interference, minimizing false positives.

borisov.name: Nikita Borisov
borisov.bio:
My name is Nikita Borisov. I am a DevOps developer in the team. I am engaged in the entire infrastructure and automation of various processes. I study at the Moscow Aviation Institute at the Information Security Faculty.

Our project is aimed at improving the ability to detect oil spills and increasing the speed of making accurate decisions.

In the process of creating the project, I actively used Docker, k8s, Docker-compose, Prometheus, Grafana and Yandex cloud.

anisimov.name: Ivan Anisimov
anisimov.bio:
My name is Ivan Anisimov. In our team, I am responsible for machine learning, developing and training neural networks. I study at the Moscow Aviation Institute, in the M3O-332B-22 group.

My main task is to train the YOLOv11 model for accurate segmentation of oil spills on satellite images. For this, I used the Ultralytics library. This part of the work is extremely important, because the efficiency of the entire system depends on the quality of pollution detection.

In my free time, I enjoy sports, especially football and tennis. I love history, often listen to music and find inspiration in different genres.

I am sure that our project will bring real benefits to the environment, helping to promptly identify and eliminate oil spills.

mitrofanov.bio:
My name is Mitrofanov Bogdan. In our team, I hold the position of senior backend developer. But it will go further and will be able to gain a foothold in large companies, as a basis for developing and implementing larger-scale and more effective solutions for the protection of water resources.

Tooltips.waterAnalysis: Our system analyzes images in visible, infrared and ultraviolet spectra to detect even minor surface anomalies. Special algorithms enhance contrast and highlight potential pollution areas.
Tooltips.aiProcessing: The deep learning model was trained on over 50,000 annotated images of oil spills. It can distinguish between oil slicks, algae blooms, and natural surface phenomena with high precision.
Tooltips.spotDetection: The system classifies spills by type (crude oil, refined products, dispersants) and age (fresh spills show different spectral characteristics than weathered ones).
Tooltips.visualization: Interactive maps show spill locations with estimated size and trajectory predictions. Reports include statistics, historical comparisons, and recommended response actions.
